thread.title: No. 4 McDonogh, No. 7 Spalding trying to stay in hunt for MIAA 'A' title
thread.title_full: No. 4 McDonogh, No. 7 Spalding trying to stay in hunt for MIAA 'A' title

author: Rich Scherr
title: No. 4 McDonogh, No. 7 Spalding trying to stay in hunt for MIAA 'A' title
text:
No. 4 McDonogh, No. 7 Spalding trying to stay in hunt for MIAA 'A' title Evan Fochtman Karl Merton Ferron / Baltimore Sun 
Archbishop Spalding Cavaliers quarterback Evan Fochtman is chased by Gilman Greyhounds cornerback Carlton Taylor (21) and linebacker Shane Lee (8). Gilman handed Spalding a 48-7 defeat. 
Archbishop Spalding Cavaliers quarterback Evan Fochtman is chased by Gilman Greyhounds cornerback Carlton Taylor (21) and linebacker Shane Lee (8). Gilman handed Spalding a 48-7 defeat. (Karl Merton Ferron / Baltimore Sun) Rich Scherr The Baltimore Sun 
No. 4 McDonogh (4-2) at No. 7 Archbishop Spalding (6-2) 
When: Friday, 7 p.m. 
Coaches: Dom Damico, McDonogh; Kyle Schmitt, Archbishop Spalding 
Last meeting: McDonogh won, 35-14, last season 
KEY PLAYERS TO WATCH 
McDonogh: RB-OLB Mylique McGriff, Jr.; MLB Andrew Frailer, Jr.; T Jordan Mcnair, Jr.; QB Jansen Durham, Sr.; WR-FS Eric Burrell; DT Alton Lacks, Sr. 
Archbishop Spalding: QB Evan Fochtman, Jr.; RB-OLB Josh Chase, Sr.; WR-CB David Harding, Sr.; OL-DL Cody Winokur, Soph.; TW-FB-OLB Mike Mancuso, Sr.; OL-LB Daniel Hood, Soph.; OL-LB Nick Vermillion, Jr. 
KEYS TO VICTORY 
There may be three weeks left in the regular season, but for McDonogh and Archbishop Spalding, the playoffs start now. 
Each team finds itself in a veritable must-win situation entering Friday night, both a game behind in the loss column to Maryland Interscholastic Athletic Association A Conference-leader Gilman. While the Cavaliers (3-1 in the conference) missed their chance to move into first place last week with a 48-7 loss to the Greyhounds, wins in their final two league games would at least keep them in contention. Mount Saint Joseph beats McDonogh 
Alvonte Thompson, senior running back for No. 7 Mount Saint Joseph football, after he scored the game-winning touchdown on a 3-yard run in double overtime to upset No. 2 McDonogh. (Katherine Dunn/Baltimore Sun video) 
Alvonte Thompson, senior running back for No. 7 Mount Saint Joseph football, after he scored the game-winning touchdown on a 3-yard run in double overtime to upset No. 2 McDonogh. (Katherine Dunn/Baltimore Sun video) See more videos 
The Eagles (2-1), on the other hand, control their own destiny, and could claim a conference title with wins in each of their final three games, including a Nov. 7 home meeting with Gilman. While the two teams shared the title last season, the league rules now have been adjusted to break ties through head-to-head matchups. 
"I've been telling our kids for the past two weeks that we're in playoff mode," McDonogh coach Dom Damico said. "You can't have two losses. We're just telling the kids, `We have two more games before we have to play for the championship. If you want the right to play in the championship game against Gilman … then we need to take care of business the next two weeks.' Hopefully we'll get a playoff-like effort." 
That would start with another big day from running back Mylique McGriff, who gained 1,275 yards a year ago but has been slowed this season after suffering a concussion that forced him to miss the Eagles game against Mount Saint Joseph — its lone conference loss. 
Damico wants his team to focus on run-blocking and controlling the line of scrimmage 
"[The Cavaliers] play a three-man front, and all three of those kids are very aggressive," Damico said. "I would like to see our team just improve a little bit in our run blocking. If we can block their three down guys, that would make me happy, and I think we'd be making some progress toward becoming a better offensive team." 
While McDonogh is looking for improvement, Spalding is also looking for a bit of redemption following last week's blowout loss to Gilman. In that game, the Cavaliers gave up 42 points in the first half after having allowed just 41 in their previous five games. 
"We don't think Gilman is 41 points better than us," Spalding coach Kyle Schmitt said. "We were really disappointed, starting with me, right down to the kids. I told the kids, `That's the beauty of sports, the ability to bounce back a week later.' And I wouldn't want to play anyone else but the other perceived power in the league. It's a great opportunity for us." 
The Cavaliers are led by dual-threat quarterback Evan Fochtman (1,422 yards passing with 19 touchdowns, 564 yards rushing with nine touchdowns) and running back Josh Chase (926 yards rushing, five touchdowns). 
To have a chance to win, Schmitt said his team needs to do a better job of stopping the run, play at a faster overall pace and get off to a quicker start than last week, when a pair of first-quarter interceptions spelled disaster. 
"I put too much on Evan's plate last week, and that was my fault as a head coach," Schmitt said. "We want to kind of get back to who we are this week. We like to run the football … and take our shots downfield. When we put ourselves in situations where it's second-and-5, our whole playbook is open." 
McDonogh has won three of the past four games in the series, including each of the past two years. For Spalding, however, this one will be critical. 
"If we want to be alive on Nov. 7, that last weekend of the season, we have to win Friday night," Schmitt said. 
OTHER GAMES TO WATCH 
No. 12 Mervo at Edmondson, Friday, 3 p.m. 
Friendship Academy at No. 1 Gilman, Friday, 3:30 p.m. 
No. 10 Broadneck at No. 2 Old Mill, Friday, 6:30 
No. 11 Annapolis at Chesapeake-AA, Friday, 6:30 p.m. 
New Town vs. No. 9 Eastern Tech at CCBC-Essex, Friday, 7 p.m.
